title: Something in my PC first died, then I killed the PSU. A repair dwindle boogaloo. A man versus technology narration that will move all rationale you've got left into computer repair. A simple ... ;;; Perchance ;;;.
self_text: Hello Redditors! Very,  very  funny story happened today. Well, not for me, but that's not the point.     It had been a beautiful morning of Eight of November. A young, yet aspiring man hath riseth from his bed, waddled to his seat, and henceforth the story fully began. He awoke his computer from sleep as always, and frittered away the time. Seconds felt like pure blissful eons, as he scrolled through the endless internet. He decided to start a long dead game called Evolve, and start it he did, indeed. 10 minutes into a thousandth match of his life, his PC  suddenly   shut down . This has happened before.     "A power outage it must've been!"  , - he thinks to himself. But, as swiftly as he came to that conclusion, he just as quickly noticed the contradiction in front of him, as well as above him. Ceiling lights remained on, and router remained on as well. By this time - the computer has already started turning itself back on. He waits 15 seconds for the splash image to arrive - but it never does. So, he resets the computer. Still nothing.  Coincidentally, he notices that the mouse and keyboard lights aren't coming on either, so he grabs his pluggable USB voltage meter and plugs it into his USB ports - it reads 3.5V. 1.5V lower than intended. Instantly, frightened of data loss, he turns off the computer and removes all drives. Then, he grabs his voltmeter and measures 12V, 5V and 3.3V rails of the PSU. He reads 9.5V, 3.5V and 2.7V. All lower. Not good. He thinks it's a bad PSU when he notices that his motherboard has LED debugging LEDs. He reads what the LED says - the "CPU FAULT" LED is on. What could it be?   The introduction has been pretty simple so far.   Sudden shutdown  Won't post, but fans spin  Low voltage on all rails, but...  IS IT?   the story continues     He decides to remove the GPU as well, to prevent the damage to it, as he remembers the GPU has very sensitive MOSFETs that operate in a specific voltage saturation region and low voltage could kill them. Besides, the computer has integrated graphics, so that's not a problem.     Correcting steps, commence!       With only PSU, Motherboard, RAM and CPU remaining in the case, he decides to clear the BIOS via BIOS jumper as well as remove the BIOS battery for 30 minutes. He does it, no change.    He decides to shuffle ram, no change.    Voltage gets measured again, and this time..  SURPRISE!  Voltages are good and within spec! 12V, 4.98V and 3.3V!    He decides to take out PSU completely and to the paperclip test - it works great! So..  is it not the psu after all?      What do we know so far?   Voltages seem to be fine now  Still no post  Paperclip PSU test works ok   What happened next?    Stupidest moment of the story begins!   Next loical step in diagnostic would be reseating the CPU, possibly a new one and trying a second motherboard. As motherboards are more expensive than cheapest compatible CPU, he decides to get a CPU. However, the seller said it will have to wait until tomorrow, so he grows impatient. He searches the internet a bit about the problem a Youtube video about an user facing the exact same issue and solving it! And the comment section is FULL or positive replies. So he decides to try it!      How is it done?   Simple, turn on your PC that won't post, and then quickly shift your ON/OFF switch on the PSU back and forth, quickly as in crazy fast.  I did that once, nothing happened. Second time, nothing. I guessed I was too slow. Third time I'll try it super fast, I thought to myself. So I do it and - woo! Power outage for real!! Wait - that's my breakers popping. Wait hold on did my PSU just blo-----.   Yes.    Yes it did.    So all in all my beloved Redditors, now I'm stuck with a dead PSU and either a dead motherboard or CPU. I'm out of ideas or any thoughts at all, so I hoped that you'd have something to share in the comments.     Thanks for reading, love you all.

title: Creating new Smart Home
self_text: Hi all!  In my previous apartment I had a really nice Home Assistant setup, but some time has passed since then and my conditions changed a lot, so I need some help to get me started.  In the old apartment I used Sonoff devices to control the lights and heating. For thermostats I used Mijia bluetooth devices and everything worked just great...  I currently have a couple of Nest Mini and Nest Hub devices that shall be used for voice control. I also have a Xiaomi desk lamp and a Roborock cleaning robot. I plan to display the Home Assistant dashboard on the Nest Hubs, but I am not sure how that actually works. I have seen the cast option, but still have 2 questions:   Is casting a 2 way control, or is it just for showing the dashboard?  Can I make the cast always available on the Hub, so that the user can switch between different things on the Hub?   Now I need a solution for my radiators. I have seen that the Bosch has released a new version of their Zigbee thermostats. I have shortly used them and they had a problem with overshooting the temperature a lot. I quess that they have fixed that by now with an update, but if I connect HA directly to thermostats without a bridge, I wouldn't get the updates. The other option would be to get Tado devices, which are not Zigbee, but I have seen that they should work with HomeKit in Home Assistant. I guess that Tado software is more mature than Bosch and has more functionality overall. Finally, I could get Aqara thermostats for almost the same money as Tado, but I was not really impressed with the build quality...   Is there any way to update the devices without a bridge and cloud, but directly via Zigbee for example?  Das Tado work locally with HA and HomeKit?  How does Tado integrate into HA?    I plan to automate lighting again, but this time probably with Shelly devices instead of Sonoff. I guess they are a fair bit better too...  Which Zigbee stick would you choose? ConBee II or Sonoff Plus?   Do you maybe have some other advice for me? What should I consider or take care about?  Thanks a lot!!! :)

title: So, AMD is doing what Nvidia did with 4080 variants, right?
self_text: I read an article in wich the AMD chief architect confirmed that the 7900 cards are both targeted to battle against the 4080, looking at the specifications.   So basically AMD is doing what Nvidia did with the 4080 versions, "masking" cards with an higher tier name to bump up prices, and not with just one card but two.  The only reason AMD "shine" it's because Nvidia cards are insanely more expensive but in the end is the same kind of scam.  Here is one of the articles talking about it: https://gamerant.com/amd-radeon-rx-7900-xtx-designed-compete-nvidia-rtx-4080-not-4090/

title: Got malware after being dumb but removed it within minutes, am I safe?
self_text: So basically I was dumb and got malware from something I definitely should not have downloaded, but I picked up on it within minutes of infection and quickly scanned with Malwarebytes. It found 110 items, so I quickly quarantined and deleted them. Of course, it didn't come without complications, and over the last few days or so I've had multiple accounts attempted to be hacked. I made sure to change all passwords and have every single kind of protection on my accounts, and I've been vigilantly watching them to make sure I'm in the clear. Here's the thing though, while my computer is running pretty much as it should and I feel mostly safe, there's still something in the back of my mind that's telling me that it isn't safe, and I've noticed certain things like commands in Chrome take twice or three times to respond (Like CTRL + T and CTRL + W), and the fact that I've scanned with Malwarebytes in safe mode and it hasn't picked up on anything which makes me believe there's something still hiding somewhere. I've pretty much installed a good portion of the reputable antivirus programs out there (Bitdefender, Malwarebytes, Hitmanpro, etc.), none of which have picked up anything since the original infection, and I've even considered using Norton Power Eraser as well. I know a lot of you will say to just wipe and reinstall Windows, but it's incredibly time consuming and I'm not sure I'm able to currently.   Sorry if this is incredibly long, I'm just not sure what I should do going forward. Any advice is incredibly appreciated.

title: Home Theater setup - need some advice
self_text: Hello all! New to this subreddit, need some help as I'm trying to wrap my brain around a (complex to me) configuration issue.  Here's where I'm at:  I have an Xbox one X in a closet in my "Theater" room. I run an optical HDMI cable through the wall and up into the attic over to my  Optoma UHD30 Projector.This has worked fine, however, the audio from this projector is absolutely horrible.  I recently purchased a Sonos Beam and 2 Sonos SL's in a "Surround" setup. I currently have the Optical Audio converter cable to a ridiculously long HDMI cable ran on the ground to the Beam... which is not ideal and will not be permanent. Currently, I'm not getting true surround on the Sonos system and I think it has to do with the Optical Audio.  Here's where I need the beautiful brains of the internet to point me in the right direction. I'd ideally like to use some sort of HDMI splitter to extract audio via HDMI and have that go into an HDMI wireless transmitter. I've searched around online and nothing really stands out as a solid solution.  Or- perhaps I'm going at this the wrong way. I'm open to advice if anyone's willing to share!  Pardon the mess in the images, I have 2 kids that like to throw stuff everywhere :P  https://preview.redd.it/4qyqomr91nz91.jpg?width=4000&format=pjpg&auto=webp&s=bacb2aca26030cfa3322ef9486254c07a8775682  https://preview.redd.it/uqp2ior91nz91.jpg?width=3000&format=pjpg&auto=webp&s=3929248899121e4beddb7380cd3905aeaa96fa61  https://preview.redd.it/97uhjpr91nz91.jpg?width=3000&format=pjpg&auto=webp&s=e0d52b1d3cd891d335a692bd21e32110101fc4ab

title: PC randomly turns off when booting up games or doing certain things.
self_text: Hi. I was wondering if someone could help me with my computer. For the past 6 months at least, it's been randomly turning off on certain games or while booting up games. I recently bought a new motherboard, processor, cpu cooler, and ssd to try and fix this. These current specs are MSI MPG B550 Gaming Plus, Ryzen 7 5700x, GTX 1660 Super. I have 16 gb of ram and 650 watts of power. I had to do a manual bios update with the flash button on the motherboard to allow support for the processor. After fixing my computer I loaded up warzone from my harddrive and played a game. Everything went well. My brother then took a turn after me and right when he clicked to go back to the lobby, the computer, monitor, and all of the lights turned off completely. When we turned it back on, the CPU light went on so we turned it back off immediately. We then turned it on again for the CPU light to go on for a few seconds until it turned off, to then the VGA light going on and turning off, to the boot light going on and off, until it began booting normally. I reset my computer and my drives and then redownloaded windows onto my SSD. I redownloaded call of duty but every time I open it, my computer turns off. I can't even click the button to turn it back on anymore. I have to flip the power supply switch like 4 or 5 times before it finally turns on. Any help is much appreciated.

title: GPU Fans keep starting and stopping no matter what I set the threshold temperature to

Ideally, I would prefer not to just have them running constantly as I like idle fan stop as a feature but this is really frustrating to hear when I'm not in-game. Any ideas?

I've set it to 1.35V which is clearly over 1.25V. Does the 1.25V means it's only the RAM's base voltage, not the upper limit I can set and I can safely set it to 1.35V?

title: I really don’t want to receive a motherboard that doesn’t work
self_text: So, the final part of my build will be my motherboard. I originally laid everything out, then slowly started researching every individual part and how well it could work with each other part. PSU and motherboard seemed to be the most problematic ones. Eventually I got the PSU figured out (at least thats what I think), but the motherboard is still just… uncertain. I found a psu that seemed to pass all the tests, yet every single b550 motherboard I research seems to have some problem. And its tricky too… I search amazon and go straight to the one star reviews. Filter out some more blatant DOA reviews. There was one board I had my eyes set on, the ASUS ROG Strix B550-A (also applies to F), and there is just a massive undiscussed issue with its ethernet ports apparently, they just dont work for many people. Every single board has this weird problem or multiple problems, and all I can think every single time is “wow, I would pay more so I can avoid that issue.” But while that may work for psu’s, it seems that the reviews play volleyball with the manufacturers— “never buying an msi product again. Plugged in x asus board and worked perfectly.” Reverse that on the asus product page.   I hate that uncertainty. Maybe Im just a baby though. What I suppose Im asking is, when it comes to b550’s, which is the best brand/model that can be proven (preferably through a reliable reviewing tech site)? Or is it not proven and just hearsay?

title: RTX 3060 display disconnecting
self_text: Hello,  I built my girlfriend a PC about a year ago, and I've just recently found out that since it was built, the display tends to cut out every hour or so.   Issue   About every hour, the display will turn black as if the cable was disconnected. The monitor will receive no signal for about 2-3 seconds and then it kicks back in.   Specs   Gigabyte RTX 3060  AMD Ryzen 5 3600  Corsair Vengeance RGB DDR4 (2*8gb)  MSI B550 Tomahawk Max +WiFi  Corsair RM 750W PSU  Asus ROG 1080p@144hz Display  Windows 10 Home   Attempted Solutions   I have tried the display on a separate PC and the issue does not occur.  I have updated the video drivers to the latest version, including a clean install.  I am going to poke around in the BIOS to see if there's any settings there that might be the issue.

title: Question: Game Design - do I need to add "complications"? / "depth"?
self_text: G'Day  In the last week or so I've put together a game on my PC - which is mainly for my own personal benefit - I have no expectation that others will play it.  It's a space battle game - that shows fancy space battles being fought in spectacular fashion. I enjoy just watching the battles.  I know however that other players would probably expect more depth to the game. They might expect a proper, well structure story based campaign? Or a map campaign? Or similar.  They might expect more gameplay mechanics.  However - I like it as it is currently.  Although I know that I could add such things as described above if I wanted to.  I'm working on the assumption - which I don't want to debate here - that no one will play it, as that has  been the case with everything I've made for 30+ years. And that's fine.  ​  But - I kind of feel that I really should spend the time putting a proper campaign of some sort into the game - with either a map or a story based campaign.  ​  What do you think? Should I leave it to play simply as a bit of a 'screen saver' type idle thingy, or should I actually add a real campaign to the game?  ​  Thoughts?

title: The calories are more accurate, as I entered my leanmass instead of my weight.
self_text: I'm at 100kg and my resting calories on the apple watch were like 2400kcal, which is waaay too much. At the end of the day the calories burned were at like 3000kcal, although I did nothing on that day.   My body fat percentage is approximately 25%, so my leanmass would be 75kg.  Now my calories are much more accurate.  Just try it out if you think the calories on your apple watch are way off.

title: Worth upgrading CPU from i5-9600k with RTX3070?
self_text: My current specs are RTX 3070 i5 9600k oced to 4.8Ghz DDR4 3200 16gb  I just recently upgraded my RTX2060 to 3070 and feel a strong bottleneck from CPU (I was aware of it thats why I'm thinking about the change). I was thinking to upgrade to I7-12700k but is it worth the upgrade cost+motherboard? I'm a fps junkie and run a 240hz monitor so more fps I can pull the better. What are your opinions?

I would also prefer the months to be able to swivel so one monitor can be vertical for programming.  Thanks!

title: Pixel shy after negative Pixel 6 experience. Is Pixel 7 really better?
self_text: After using iPhones for over a decade I'm wanting to switch to an Android. Last year I bought a Pixel 6 on release day and spent the next 10 months regretting it. When it worked I loved the device. Unfortunately my Pixel 6 plagued with bugs and glitches that each update couldn't seem to fix. The only issue that improved was the fingerprint sensor thanks to the March 2022 update. In July 2022 I just couldn't take anymore of this awesome yet extremely buggy experience. So I sold the Pixel 6 and bought an iPhone 13. The iPhone 13 works perfectly with no bugs or glitches, but is so boring and limiting.  Since the release of the Pixel 7, I've heard people say the Pixel 7 is the Pixel 6 fixed and best Pixel so far. I want to believe this. After all, when my Pixel 6 wasn't acting buggy/glitchy the experience was amazing. I want to make the permeant switch to Android. Specifically Google's version of Android due to the fact I currently use nearly all of Google's services. So the Pixel seems like the device for me, but I need to know this device is seriously reliable. I mean iPhone reliable. The iPhone is extremely boring, but it's also extremely reliable. Is the Pixel 7 reliable? If I buy one, will I spend the following months regretting it again???

title: Orange DRAM Light
self_text: I updated my PC with some new parts. Replaced everything except my GPU, RAM, and hard drives. I got the PC to boot to BIOS and was messing around with the DRAM speed and changed the speed to 3600 MHz (ram is rated for 3600).  When I rebooted, I didn't get any video out and now have an orange DRAM Light on my board.   Is there a way to hard reset the BIOS since I can't get any video out? I tried reseating the ram a bunch of different ways and now have the CMOS battery out. Is there anything else I can do or is my Mobo/ram bricked?
